title: Our Rapidly Changing World...

content: China is the number 1 English speaking nation. What's the definition of a third world country again? We are slipping and contrary to right wing indoctrination, it's mostly our fault. We no longer value education, in fact we seem to despise it. It's not Mexicans crossing the border that is our main threat. It's institutionalized ignorance.
reply: China is the number 1 English speaking nation. What's the definition of a third world country again? We are slipping and contrary to right wing indoctrination, it's mostly our fault. We no longer value education, in fact we seem to despise it. It's not Mexicans crossing the border that is our main threat. It's institutionalized ignorance.
title: Our Rapidly Changing World...

content: quote: Originally posted by Thud357L: China is the number 1 English speaking nation. What's the definition of a third world country again? We are slipping and contrary to right wing indoctrination, it's mostly our fault. We no longer value education, in fact we seem to despise it. It's not Mexicans crossing the border that is our main threat. It's institutionalized ignorance. You're right. But you can look direclty at the policys of the left as to why. The entrie: we are all equal, movement..the culture of never saying anything is wrong, the inability to make a judgement call about anything.. Beyond that the fight against English only schools..when by every measure they are better..the fight for teacher unions, which have crippled our education system.. In my state, you must, BY LAW, teach every child in that childs native language. So, if you live in a city with dozens of differant nationalities, all of whom are illegal..then you need to have a teacher, for every subject, for every langauge for every student. Thats INSANE. The push to send every child to college..INSANE. The only way to do that is to LOWER standards. Right now, kids are going to colleges that have no business claming a high school degree. Yet, you and I, are going to pay to send children to school that cant meet the standards.

It's not Mexicans crossing the border that is our main threat. It's institutionalized ignorance.

The push to send every child to college..INSANE. The only way to do that is to LOWER standards. Right now, kids are going to colleges that have no business claming a high school degree. content: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by Thud357L: China is the number 1 English speaking nation. What's the definition of a third world country again? We are slipping and contrary to right wing indoctrination, it's mostly our fault. We no longer value education, in fact we seem to despise it. It's not Mexicans crossing the border that is our main threat. It's institutionalized ignorance. You're right. But you can look direclty at the policys of the left as to why. The entrie: we are all equal, movement..the culture of never saying anything is wrong, the inability to make a judgement call about anything.. Beyond that the fight against English only schools..when by every measure they are better..the fight for teacher unions, which have crippled our education system.. In my state, you must, BY LAW, teach every child in that childs native language. So, if you live in a city with dozens of differant nationalities, all of whom are illegal..then you need to have a teacher, for every subject, for every langauge for every student. Thats INSANE. The push to send every child to college..INSANE. The only way to do that is to LOWER standards. Right now, kids are going to colleges that have no business claming a high school degree. Yet, you and I, are going to pay to send children to school that cant meet the standards. Policies of the left? In this one, everybody is guilty. The right values legend over science and has branded higher education as a "nest for leftist, intellectual traitors". What city do you live in? I'll agree that such a policy is totally unmanageable. I think budget realities will solve that one. It's not a push to send every child to college, rather it's trying to make it so that every child can go to college that can meet the standards. So we don't have to lower standards, just give universal access to qualified students. I really don't mind paying a bit extra so that qualified students can get a leg up. What worries me more is the education mills that turn out graduates that can't read at a third grade level. It's not only public schools but charter schools too. Since they're profit based, they may be even more guilty.

content: this is from a few years back, but..it still applies today..and it's sad.. "http://www.bus.lsu.edu/accounting/faculty/lcrumbley/deliberatedumbing.html" quote: something is terribly wrong when a $6,330 per pupil expenditure produces such pathetic results. This writer has visited private schools which charge $1,000-per-year in tuition which enjoy superior academic results. Parents of home-schooled children spend a maximum of $1,000-per-year and usually have similar excellent results. Part of the problem in American Schools, is they expect teachers to do more than teach academics..they need to get back to the basics of education, and stop trying to 'teach' everything else.. "http://www.sntp.net/education/education_stats.htm" quote: If demographics, television, IQ, and money do not account for the differences, attitudes certainly do. Americans have very different assumptions than do their Asian counterparts about the appropriate role parents should play in the education of their children. Asians, according to Stevenson, expect schools to develop academic skills, while they believe it is up to the home to support the schools and to provide a "healthy emotional environment." In contrast, Americans expect more of their schools and less of themselves. Stevenson says that many Americans "seem to expect that schools will take on responsibility for many more aspects of the child's life," including family roles, sex, drugs, minority relations, illnesses, nutrition, and fire prevention. and now what do they want to do?? Start teaching kids at 4 years old, with their VPK programs..years ago they didn't even have kindergarten, unless a parent paid to send their kids..now our tax dollars are going to educate 4 year olds, because they think THAT will help.. If they did away with many of the programs and focused on academics things would improve.. This is why so many folks are choosing to home school their kids.. "http://whyhomeschool.blogspot.com/2007/07/dumming-down-trend.html" This message has been edited. Last edited by: 3678131, Sat 25 April 2009 02:40 PM
quote: something is terribly wrong when a $6,330 per pupil expenditure produces such pathetic results. Parents of home-schooled children spend a maximum of $1,000-per-year and usually have similar excellent results.

In contrast, Americans expect more of their schools and less of themselves. Stevenson says that many Americans "seem to expect that schools will take on responsibility for many more aspects of the child's life," including family roles, sex, drugs, minority relations, illnesses, nutrition, and fire prevention. and now what do they want to do?? Start teaching kids at 4 years old, with their VPK programs..years ago they didn't even have kindergarten, unless a parent paid to send their kids..now our tax dollars are going to educate 4 year olds, because they think THAT will help.. content: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by Thud357L: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by Thud357L: China is the number 1 English speaking nation. What's the definition of a third world country again? We are slipping and contrary to right wing indoctrination, it's mostly our fault. We no longer value education, in fact we seem to despise it. It's not Mexicans crossing the border that is our main threat. It's institutionalized ignorance. You're right. But you can look direclty at the policys of the left as to why. The entrie: we are all equal, movement..the culture of never saying anything is wrong, the inability to make a judgement call about anything.. Beyond that the fight against English only schools..when by every measure they are better..the fight for teacher unions, which have crippled our education system.. In my state, you must, BY LAW, teach every child in that childs native language. So, if you live in a city with dozens of differant nationalities, all of whom are illegal..then you need to have a teacher, for every subject, for every langauge for every student. Thats INSANE. The push to send every child to college..INSANE. The only way to do that is to LOWER standards. Right now, kids are going to colleges that have no business claming a high school degree. Yet, you and I, are going to pay to send children to school that cant meet the standards. Policies of the left? In this one, everybody is guilty. The right values legend over science and has branded higher education as a "nest for leftist, intellectual traitors". What city do you live in? I'll agree that such a policy is totally unmanageable. I think budget realities will solve that one. It's not a push to send every child to college, rather it's trying to make it so that every child can go to college that can meet the standards. So we don't have to lower standards, just give universal access to qualified students. I really don't mind paying a bit extra so that qualified students can get a leg up. What worries me more is the education mills that turn out graduates that can't read at a third grade level. It's not only public schools but charter schools too. Since they're profit based, they may be even more guilty. Your post deserves a more complete response..but I'm off to bed after working about 30000 hours this week. That said: I'm yet to see a problem with charter schools. You have a link? I'm sure you can find corroborating evidence on the net but I'm going by personal experience. Both grandsons attended a charter school and were receiving good grades. On Mother's day all the fellas decided to cook and clean house so the females could just relax. I discovered that Mikey couldn't read the directions off a cake box to me. I went to that school and raised hell wondering why he's getting A's and B's and can't read a cake box. When I talked to his counselor, she couldn't look me in the eye. I'm not saying public schools are any better but I think charter schools are way overrated.

title: Our Rapidly Changing World...

content: The education system in America is in ruins. Fingers can be pointed at a lot of people, institutions, etc., except at the ones at which they should be pointed. All things start at home, morals, values, etc. Schools are now expected to be all things to all students, but it doesn't work. The society has unrealistic expectations of schools. Schools are rampant with unqualified teachers, unions who fight tooth and nail against teacher testing for competence and other assorted ills. Single parent homes with numerous children who don't, apparently, take an interest in their childrens education. There are problems too numerous to list here, but they show an indifference to a civiliced society. We have become a bitter, partisan society with ills, real or imagined, perpetuated by those who are making money from keeping society in a turmoil. Many, many problems need to be adressed in our society, but unfortunately the special interests groups seem to have a stranglehold on the political systam, and no one at the grassroots level seems to have the power to begin change. Those who advocate for change are derided and humiliated until they figure it's just not worth it. If change comes, it may come in a way none of us wish for it to happen.
